Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 46070  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
June 2013 
 
 
Support for a Regional Platform on Innovations in 
Education and Human Resources Development for 
Competitiveness towards an Integrated ASEAN 
Community  
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB   –  Asian Development Bank 
  AEC  –  ASEAN Economic Community 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  GMS  –  Greater Mekong Subregion 
  HOCCS  –  high officials country case studies 
  HRD  –  human resource development 
  PPP  –  Phnom Penh Plan 
  SDEM  –  Strategic Dialogue for Education Ministers 
  SEAMEO  –  Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organization 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TVET  –  technical and vocational education and training 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional–Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Education (preprimary and basic education, nonformal education, 
upper secondary education, technical education and vocational 
skills training, tertiary and higher education) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Social development (human development), capacity 
development (institutional development, organizational 
development), regional cooperation and integration (other 
regional public goods) 
Location (impact)  –  Regional (high), rural (low), urban (low), national (medium) 
Partnership  –  Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
 
GLOSSARY 
 
college  –  An organized body of persons engaged in a common pursuit or having 
common interests or duties, or a collegial body that is not always an 
institution with a physical structure. 
innovation  –  The  introduction  of  a  new  idea,  method,  or  device,  which  can  be 
generated from informal and open dialogues among innovators. 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  J. Nugent, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Director  L. Gutierrez, Human and Social Development Division, SERD 
   
Team leader  Y. Hirosato, Principal Education Specialist, SERD 
Team member  J. Mangahas, Social Sector Specialist, SERD 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

CONTENTS 
Page 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION  1 
II.  ISSUES  1 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  3 
A.  Impact and Outcome  3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  3 
C.  Cost and Financing  4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  4 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  5 
 
APPENDIXES  
1.  Design and Monitoring Framework  6 
2.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  9 
3.  Outline Terms of Reference for SEAMEO Secretariat, SEAMEO Regional Centers, 
            and Consultants  10 
 
SUPPLEMENTARY APPENDIX (available on request) 
A.  Structure and Implementation Arrangements

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Upon the request of member countries of the Southeast Asian Ministers of Education 
Organization  (SEAMEO),  the  SEAMEO  Secretariat  submitted  a  proposal  to  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for regional technical assistance (TA) to help establish a regional 
platform  for  high-level  policy  and  strategic  dialogue  on  education  and  human  resource 
development (HRD) issues in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) region.1 
SEAMEO will offer this regional platform through the establishment of SEAMEO College. Based 
on consultations between ADB and SEAMEO, the detailed design and operational plan of 
SEAMEO College was prepared, and endorsed at the 35th SEAMEO High Officials Meeting 
from 27 to 29 November 2012, when an ADB consultation mission was fielded to discuss and 
agree on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost estimates and 
financing plan, and terms of reference of consultants.2  The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1.3 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ASEAN strives to increase regional connectivity, competitiveness, and community.4 One 
of the purposes of ASEAN is “to develop human resources through cooperation in education 
and life-long learning, and in science and technology, for the strengthening of the ASEAN 
Community.”5 ASEAN member countries share a common goal of aligning their education and 
training systems to develop their human resources toward an ASEAN Economic Community 
(AEC) in 2015 and beyond. However, ASEAN needs to accelerate activities as stipulated in its 
blueprints, particularly the AEC Blueprint.  
 
3.  Since 1965, SEAMEO, with its Secretariat and 20 regional centers, has been at the helm 
of regional cooperation in education, science, and culture in Southeast Asia.6 According to the 
ASEAN  Education  Ministers  Meeting,  ASEAN’s  cooperation  priorities  in  education  will  be 
undertaken through collaboration with SEAMEO.7 ADB and SEAMEO signed a memorandum of 
understanding to facilitate collaboration in the development of regional cooperation programs, 
including assistance from ADB to SEAMEO.8 To help achieve the AEC in 2015 and beyond, 
SEAMEO aligned and intensified its initiatives to foster human and intellectual connectivity—an 
essential ingredient for a successful AEC. 
 
4.  SEAMEO College is a high-level policy and strategy forum among education leaders and 
practitioners. It does not involve a physical campus. SEAMEO College has two main functions: 
                                                
1  SEAMEO is an international and intergovernmental organization established in 1965 to promote cooperation in 
education, science, and culture in Southeast Asia. It comprises education ministers from 11 member countries: 
Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, 
Singapore, Timor-Leste, Thailand, and Viet Nam. The SEAMEO Secretariat is the legal and administrative 
representative of SEAMEO.   
2  ADB supported the preparation of the SEAMEO College, under R-S-PATA 7957: Regional Technical Assistance to 
Support to ASEAN Leaders Forum on HRD for an Integrated ASEAN Community ($225,000, approved on 
7 December 2012). See SEAMEO Secretariat. 2012. Design and Operation Plan for the SEAMEO College. 
Bangkok.  The SEAMEO College is a flagship program under SEAMEO’s Ten-Year Strategic Plan, 2011–2020, 
and was officially launched on 20 March 2013 at the 47th SEAMEO Council Meeting held in Ha Noi, Viet Nam.  
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 14 May 2013.  
4   ASEAN. 2010. Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity. Jakarta. 
5   ASEAN. 2007. ASEAN Charter (Article 1, Purposes 10). Jakarta. 
6  Twenty SEAMEO regional centers comprise 12 regional centers for education development, six regional centers for 
science and research, and two regional centers for cultural development.   
7  ASEAN. ASEAN Education Ministers Meeting. http://www.asean.org/communities/asean-socio-cultural-community/ 
category/overview-24  
8  ADB and SEAMEO. 2003. Memorandum of Understanding between ADB and SEAMEO (signed on 25 June).

2   
(i) to create a regional platform for education ministers, high-level policy makers, prominent 
education  practitioners,  and  youth  leaders  to  regularly  convene  policy,  strategic,  and 
methodological dialogues on ASEAN-wide education and HRD issues; and (ii) through such 
dialogues,  to  bring  about frontier  innovations  in  education  and  HRD  in  ASEAN.  SEAMEO 
College, as the only concrete regional education platform to date in Southeast Asia, will help 
make the ASEAN region more competitive through strengthened capacity of education leaders 
and practitioners. The TA will help identify measures to advance education and HRD elements 
of the AEC Blueprint, and thus respond to the urgent need for assistance in accelerating the 
process of building an integrated ASEAN Community by 2015. 
 
5.  Among the ASEAN-wide education and HRD issues, SEAMEO College will focus on 
three key issues. First, disparities in education and skills attainment between low- and middle-
income countries—and among low-income countries such as Cambodia,  the Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic, Myanmar, and Viet Nam—in the ASEAN region need to be addressed. 
Second, harmonized regional frameworks for common standards in education and training are 
needed. This will focus on developing (i) mutual recognition of qualifications to facilitate the free 
flow of skilled labor in the region,9 and (ii) a common regional framework for higher education 
harmonization to enable greater student and academic mobility in ASEAN. Third, changing 
labor demand in ASEAN needs to be tackled with a view to developing a regional labor market.   
 
6.  These regional issues require innovative solutions, which SEAMEO College aims to 
provide through the collective efforts of education ministers, high-level policy makers, and 
education  and  youth  leaders.  In  particular,  innovative  ways  are  needed  for  developing  a 
productive, competitive, and mobile labor force within the ASEAN members. ADB accords high 
priority to regional cooperation and cross-border collaboration in education to help harmonize 
education and skills systems and qualifications—thereby facilitating the mobility of students, 
faculty,  and  labor;  and  strengthening  regional  integration.  By  supporting  the  promotion  of 
regional dialogue and cooperation among ASEAN members and key stakeholders in education 
and HRD, the TA is aligned with the objective of ADB’s Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Strategy.10 It is also in line with ADB’s education operations plan, which stresses the importance 
of ADB support to education, with priorities including support to new and innovative models in 
education  service  delivery  and  to  regional  cooperation  and  cross-border  collaboration  in 
education.11 SEAMEO College will link with ADB projects, particularly in higher education and 
technical and vocational education and training (TVET), and create synergy or complementarity 
at the regional policy level. The TA will also complement existing HRD programs in the Greater 
Mekong Subregion (GMS)12 and the Phnom Penh Plan (PPP) for Development Management.13 
                                                
 
9 To date, eight mutual recognition arrangements have been identified for the following professional groups: 
engineering  services,  nursing  services,  architectural  services,  surveying,  tourism  professionals,  medical 
practitioners, dental practitioners, and accountancy services. However, there has been little progress so far in 
implementation, and ASEAN-wide cooperation is required to develop a practical system for comparing and 
recognizing skills and qualifications.  
10  ADB. 2006.  Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy. Manila.  
11  ADB. 2010. Education by 2020: A Sector Operations Plan. Manila.  
 
12 ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Implementing the Greater Mekong Subregion Human Resource Development 
Strategic Framework and Action Plan. Manila (R-PATA 7275, $1.25 million, approved on 29 April); and ADB. 
Forthcoming. Strategic Framework and Action Plan for Human Resource Development in the Greater Mekong 
Subregion (2013–2017). Manila. Both GMS HRD strategic framework and action plans, 2009–2012 and 2013–
2017, include support to develop a mutual recognition framework. However, the development of such a framework 
under these plans is limited to a desk study and pilot testing of a GMS recognition framework in a few selected 
technical skill areas. The TA will complement the 2009 TA and the GMS HRD strategic framework and action plan, 
2013–2017, by extending its scope, coverage, and linkages to ASEAN-wide recognition framework of technical 
skills and qualifications.  
13 ADB.  2012.  Technical  Assistance  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Phnom  Penh  Plan  for  Development

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA is regional education and HRD innovations for a more integrated 
ASEAN Community. The outcome of the TA is strengthened capacity of education leaders and 
practitioners to address ASEAN-wide education and HRD issues. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will mainly support the delivery of specific capacity building modules and related 
research.14 It  will  have  five  outputs:  (i)  knowledge  on  regional  frameworks  for  common 
standards  in  education  and  HRD  enhanced  and  shared  among  education  policy  makers, 
(ii) regional and country case studies on innovative solutions to ASEAN-wide education and 
HRD issues developed and disseminated, (iii) policy options for learning and innovations for 
education practitioners and youth leaders identified, (iv) research capacity of SEAMEO College 
enhanced, and (v) institutional linkages of SEAMEO regional centers as integral constituents of 
SEAMEO College strengthened. 
 
9.  Output 1. The TA will support high-profile strategic dialogues among Southeast Asian 
education ministers, which will be called Strategic Dialogue for Education Ministers (SDEM) 
(module 1).15 The dialogues will be facilitated by internationally well-known eminent persons, 
world-class educators, or peer ministers of education. SDEM will be conducted once in 2014 
and once in 2015. Through SDEM, Southeast Asian education ministers will share ideas on 
regional frameworks for common standards in education and HRD.16 
 
10.  Output 2. The TA will support forward-looking discussions among high-level education 
policy makers to generate new insights and innovative solutions. The discussions will be called 
High Officials Country Case Studies (HOCCS) (module 2), based on regional and country 
case  studies  of  ASEAN-wide  education  and  HRD  issues,  especially  three  key  issues 
(para. 5). HOCCS will be conducted once in 2013 and 2014. Through HOCCS, new regional 
frameworks for common standards in support of SDEM (module 1) will be developed.  
  
11.  Output  3.  The  TA  will  support  forums  on  learning  and  innovations  that  can  be 
considered by education practitioners and youth leaders. These will be called the Education 
Leaders’  Innovation  Forum  (module  3)  and  the  Learning  and  Innovation  Forum  for  Youth 
Leaders (module 4). Both forums will be conducted once in 2013 and 2014. Practices and 
experiences will be gathered and studied with a view to promoting life and 21st century skills; 
new teaching and learning methods, including the use of new education technologies; ASEAN 
content in curricula; and school- and community-based innovations and good practices.  
 
                                                
Management V. Manila (R-CDTA 8225, $1.25 million, approved on 23 November). ADB has supported the PPP since 
2002 as a core program on HRD in the GMS. The PPP aims to develop a cadre of GMS development leaders by 
focusing on regional cooperation and middle and senior officials (but not ministers and high-level policy makers). The 
regional platform to be provided by SEAMEO College will draw experience from middle-income ASEAN countries, 
and have synergy with the PPP, for example, by joining PPP’s planned programs on labor markets in the GMS.  
14  While Timor-Leste is not included in the TA scope, SEAMEO may invite participants from Timor-Leste to activities 
related to SEAMEO College using SEAMEO’s own resources. Special consideration will be given to Myanmar in 
terms of its participation to capacity building modules and research activities.     
15 The Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction will not finance costs for the venue, travel, and per diem of participants to 
the SDEM. 
 
16 It is expected that SEAMEO will liaise with the ASEAN Secretariat in adopting regional frameworks for common 
standards as regional policy agenda at the ASEAN Summit and/or the ASEAN Education Ministers Meeting.

4   
12.  Output  4.  The  TA  will  strengthen  the  capacity  of  SEAMEO  College  to  undertake 
research in support of outputs 1–3. The topics will include (i) a review of best practices of 
innovative approaches in education and HRD within and outside the region, which can be 
adapted to Southeast Asia; (ii) mutual recognition and harmonization frameworks with common 
standards  in  TVET  and  higher  education;  (iii) supply  and  demand  forecasting  of  human 
resources in ASEAN; and (iv) post-Education for All framework and agenda beyond 2015. The 
TA  will  strengthen  the  research  network  among  SEAMEO  regional  centers  and  between 
SEAMEO regional centers and other regional research institutes and leading universities.  
 
13.  Output  5. The TA  will  strengthen  linkages  among  SEAMEO  regional  centers. This 
output  will  enable  SEAMEO  regional  centers  to  become  integral  constituents  of  SEAMEO 
College. Strengthening e-connectivity across SEAMEO regional centers will promote online 
work collaboration among SEAMEO regional centers through online meetings and conferences. 
SEAMEO regional centers will also organize six communities of practice with their knowledge 
sharing and learning websites. This will help build a network for research and development of 
education innovations in Southeast Asia. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,650,000, of which $1,400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The cost estimates 
and financing plan are in Appendix 2. SEAMEO will provide counterpart support in the form of 
office accommodation, remuneration of counterpart staff, costs of venue and travel and per 
diem of participants to SDEM (module 1), utilities, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
15.  The SEAMEO Secretariat in Bangkok will be the executing agency, and eight SEAMEO 
regional centers will be implementing agencies.17 As the legal and administrative representative 
of SEAMEO, the Secretariat will be responsible for overall TA implementation. The TA will be 
the first ASEAN-wide TA in the education and training sector directly involving ministers in 
charge of education and/or TVET, and high-level policy makers. SEAMEO has established its 
network and accumulated experience in regional cooperation in Southeast Asia, and has the 
mandate and capacity to influence education leaders and practitioners on regional education, 
and HRD initiatives. In addition to its record as an effective executing agency under previous 
regional TA (footnote 17), the SEAMEO Secretariat is a suitable executing agency for the 
following reasons: (i) SEAMEO is impartial and neutral, and can offer equal treatment to its 
member countries; (ii) SEAMEO has good communication channels with the countries involved 
in the TA; (iii) SEAMEO has successfully managed international and national consultants under 
ADB  TA  (footnote 2);  (iv)  all  SEAMEO  member  countries  endorsed  the  proposed 
implementation arrangements at the 35th SEAMEO High Official Meeting; and (v) the 47th 
SEAMEO Council Meeting approved the establishment of SEAMEO College. ADB will provide 
overall policy advice to SEAMEO on the management and implementation of SEAMEO College, 
and  engage  in  policy  dialogue  with  education  ministers  and  high-level  policy  makers  by 
participating in selected activities under the TA. The recruitment of consultants, procurement of 
equipment, and disbursement will remain with ADB.  
                                                
17 The SEAMEO Secretariat was the executing agency and selected SEAMEO regional centers were the implementing 
agencies for ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance for ICT and HIV/AIDS Preventive Education in the Cross-Border Areas 
of  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion.  Manila  (REG-6083:  $1  million,  approved  on  19  December  2002)  (rated 
successful). SEAMEO has executed and implemented a number of activities financed by contributions from SEAMEO 
member countries and development partners, including ADB and the World Bank.

5 
16.  The advisory board—comprising prominent scholars and professionals, representatives 
from the private sector, the director of the SEAMEO Secretariat, and responsible ADB staff such 
as a representative from the concerned division—will serve as a project steering committee, and 
guide  implementation  of  the  TA  at  the  policy  level.  The  project  management  committee, 
comprising  selected  SEAMEO  Secretariat  and  SEAMEO  regional  center  staff,  will  provide 
oversight of TA implementation. The project management office, which is equivalent to a project 
implementation unit and is headed by a project manager and staffed by project officers, will 
implement the day-to-day activities of the TA and report to the project management committee. 
The project management office will be located on the premises of the SEAMEO Secretariat. The 
structure and implementation arrangements are in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
17.  Consulting services under the TA will flexibly respond to requests of the governments of 
SEAMEO member countries. About 108 person-months of international and national consultants 
will be recruited by ADB. Consultants will require highly specialized knowledge on ASEAN-wide 
education and HRD issues, and extensive networks with education ministers, high-level policy 
makers,  education  administrators  and  practitioners,  and  youth  leaders  in  ASEAN member 
countries. A firm is unlikely to gather such specialized expertise and extensive networks in a 
single team. Consultants will be recruited on an individual basis in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). About 22 resource 
persons will be engaged on an individual basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants, including (i) internationally well-known eminent persons such as representatives 
from the private sector to serve as speakers during capacity building modules of SEAMEO 
College; (ii) prominent scholars, professionals, and representatives from the private sector who 
will provide specific inputs to the advisory board; (iii) regional experts who will provide specific 
inputs to the project management committee; and (iv) experts on education policy research who 
will mainly prepare and deliver workshops on education policy research. 
 
18.  For the workshops, training, seminars, conferences, and surveys  under the TA, an 
advance payment facility will be established at the executing agency. Disbursement under the 
TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time). The eligibility or ineligibility of expenditures will be guided by 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction policies and guidelines for TA.18 Office equipment under the 
TA will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from 
time to time), and on completion of the TA, the SEAMEO Secretariat will retain all equipment to 
be used in operating SEAMEO College. It is expected that the TA will commence in July 2013 
and be completed in June 2015. The outline terms of reference for the SEAMEO Secretariat, 
SEAMEO regional centers, and consultants are in Appendix 3. ADB will obtain a no-objection 
from the developing member country government before starting any activity financed under this 
TA in the territory of that country. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,400,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Support for a Regional Platform on 
Innovations in Education and Human Resources Development for Competitiveness towards an 
Integrated ASEAN Community, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
18 ADB. Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 2013 Policy Guidelines for Technical Assistance Grants.

education and training. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

Appendix 2  9 
COST ESTIMATES AND FINANCING PLAN 
($’000) 
Item  Amount 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reductiona   
      1.  Consultants   
  a.   Remuneration and per diem   
                  i.   International consultants  329.0 
                  ii.  National consultants                                                       147.0                                                                                                                               
                  iii. Resource persons  220.0 
            b.   International and local travel  170.0 
  c.   Reports and communications  34.0 
      2.   Workshops, training, seminars, and conferencesb   290.0 
      3.   Equipmentc  30.0

Note: The technical assistance (TA) is estimated to cost $1,650,000, of which contributions from the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction are presented in the table above. The Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organization 
(SEAMEO) will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, remuneration of counterpart staff, 
cost of venue and travel and per diem of participants to Strategic Dialogue for Education Ministers (SDEM), utilities, 
and other in-kind contributions. The value of the SEAMEO contribution is estimated to account for 15.2% of the total 
TA cost. 
 a   Administered by the Asian Development Bank. 
b Cost of venue, and travel and per diem of participants to SDEM will not be financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction. While SEAMEO’s own resources will cover such cost, other resources will be tapped and, should they 
become available, will support the cost of SDEM (venue, travel, and per diem of participants).   
c Equipment comprising computer laptops and notebooks, associated software, external drives, camera, 3-in-1 
photocopier/printer/scanner, computer server, fax machine, mobile phones, and webcam for multiple users. On 
completion of the TA, the SEAMEO Secretariat will retain all equipment to be used in operating SEAMEO College. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

10          Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR SEAMEO SECRETARIAT,                                  
SEAMEO REGIONAL CENTERS, AND CONSULTANTS 
A.  SEAMEO Secretariat and SEAMEO Regional Centers 
 
1.  The  Southeast  Asian  Ministers  of  Education  Organization  (SEAMEO)  Secretariat, 
serving as the executing agency of the technical assistance (TA), will  
(i)  provide administrative and financial support services to SEAMEO College; 
(ii)  provide guidance in the management of SEAMEO College by the secretariat 
director serving as chairperson of the advisory board and by the secretariat 
deputy director serving as chairperson of the project management committee; 
and  
(iii)  coordinate  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  the  SEAMEO  regional 
centers,  and  development  partners  to  facilitate  the  performance  of  project 
activities.  
 
2.  SEAMEO  regional  centers,  serving  as  implementing  agencies,  will  undertake  the 
following general tasks:1 
(i)  implement components and activities of SEAMEO College; 
(ii)  undertake collaborative research among SEAMEO regional centers; 
(iii)  upgrade the competencies of SEAMEO regional centers’ staff to better undertake 
collaborative research and training activities geared to support the four capacity 
building modules of SEAMEO College, such as education policy research, and 
research and development in educational innovations; 
(iv)  provide expertise, knowledge, information, and institutional networking in support 
of SEAMEO College; 
(v)  provide  support  to  other  SEAMEO  regional  centers  through  participation  in 
collaborative projects under SEAMEO College through secondment or cross-
posting of specialists and project officers with the project management office 
(PMO), and inter-center mentoring activities; 
(vi)  build expertise, equipment, and capacities within own SEAMEO regional centers 
to enhance community of practice among staff through online communication, 
instruction  of  collaborating  with  other  SEAMEO  regional  centers  and 
stakeholders for the operations of SEAMEO College; and  
(vii)  assist in promoting and publicizing SEAMEO College and its programs. 
 
                                                
1  Eight SEAMEO regional centers will be selected as implementing agencies, based on the centers’ degree of 
(i) involvement in the preparation of SEAMEO College; and (ii) readiness, relevance of experience, and capacity in 
implementing activities under SEAMEO College as the lead SEAMEO regional centers. The roles, tasks, and 
responsibilities of the SEAMEO regional centers in SEAMEO College will not include their existing and ongoing 
activities. SEAMEO College is the sum of all the expertise of the 20 SEAMEO regional centers—a consortium to 
provide know-how and address needs that no single SEAMEO regional center is able to do. Each SEAMEO 
regional center’s programs are focused on a unique regional and national mandate. Their expected roles and 
responsibilities in SEAMEO College are regional and collaborative in nature; and add to their existing mandate, 
programs, and activities. SEAMEO College brings all the SEAMEO regional centers together to operate as one and 
address ASEAN-wide issues in education and human resource development, and help provide a regional platform 
for dialogue for specific target groups. SEAMEO College will not duplicate any existing programmes of SEAMEO 
regional  centers.  Instead,  SEAMEO  regional  centers  will  pool  their  expertise,  knowledge,  resources,  and 
experiences; and will intensify and accelerate their activities for high-level solutions through SEAMEO College with 
the involvement of education and training ministers.

Appendix 3  11 
3.  The eight selected SEAMEO regional centers, as implementing agencies, will undertake 
the following tasks in collaboration with all and/or selected SEAMEO centers. 
 
4.  SEAMEO Regional Centre for Educational Innovation and Technology. As a lead 
center, and in cooperation with the Regional Training Centre (RETRAC) and SEAMEO Regional 
Centre for Lifelong Learning (CELLL), the SEAMEO Regional Centre for Educational Innovation 
and Technology (INNOTECH) will  
(i)  lead  the  design,  development,  and  conduct  of  the  Strategic  Dialogue  of 
Education Ministers (SDEM) (module 1); 
(ii)  develop  and  disseminate  innovative  and  technology-oriented  educational 
programs  to  help  solve  common  or  unique  educational  needs  identified  by 
education ministers in SDEM; 
(iii)  provide training and flexible learning programs and solutions to educators and 
practitioners in collaboration with SEAMEO RETRAC in the Education Leaders’ 
Innovation Forum (ELIF) (module 3), such as blended learning on various topics 
and themes including education supervision, teaching and learning excellence, 
change management, and peace education; 
(iv)  conduct  collaborative  research  and  case  studies  on  regional  innovations  on 
education, including the post-Education for All framework and agenda beyond 
2015; and 
(v)  review best practices of innovative approaches in education and human resource 
development (HRD) within and outside the region, which can be adapted to 
Southeast Asia. 
  
5.  SEAMEO Regional Centre for Higher Education and Development. As a lead center, 
and in cooperation with the Regional Centre for Graduate Study and Research in Agriculture 
(SEARCA)  and  SEAMEO  Regional  Centre  for  Tropical  Biology  (BIOTROP),  the  SEAMEO 
Regional Center for Higher Education and Development (RIHED) will  
(i)  lead  the  design,  development,  and  conduct  of  High  Officials  Country  Case 
Studies (HOCCS) (module 2) for high or senior education officials; 
(ii)  provide  capacity  building  on  higher  education  policy  development,  planning, 
administration, and management; 
(iii)  conduct  research  on  higher  education,  standardization,  and  accreditation 
including mobility of students and faculties in the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN); and 
(iv)  organize forums and consultations on higher education harmonization. 
 
6.  SEAMEO  Regional  Training  Centre.  As  a  lead  center,  and  in  cooperation  with 
SEAMEO  CELLL,  SEAMEO  INNOTECH,  and  SEAMEO  RIHED,  the  SEAMEO  Regional 
Training Center (RETRAC) will  
(i)  lead the design, development, and conduct of ELIF (module 3) for education 
practitioners; 
(ii)  set up and assist in maintaining a learning and innovation community among 
participants and graduates of module 3; 
(iii)  conduct research on the basic education quality assurance and curriculum, and 
equity in education and access; and 
(iv)  provide training for school administrators and teachers on basic education, based 
on the results of the research.

12  Appendix 3 
 
7.  SEAMEO Regional Centre for Archaeology and Fine Arts. As a lead center, and in 
cooperation with SEAMEO BIOTROP and SEAMEO Regional Language Centre (RELC), the 
SEAMEO Regional Centre for Archaeology and Fine Arts (SPAFA) will 
(i)  lead  the  design,  development,  and  conduct  of  the  Learning  and  Innovation 
Forum of Youth Leaders (LIFYL) (module 4); 
(ii)  organize  forums,  exchanges,  and  exhibitions  for  youth  leaders  to  showcase 
emerging trends, issues, challenges, and opportunities in ASEAN; and 
(iii)  conduct  research  on  intercultural  studies,  including  bilingualism  and 
multilingualism, in Southeast Asia. 
 
8.  SEAMEO Regional Open Learning Centre. As a lead center, and in cooperation with 
INNOTECH and SEARCA, the SEAMEO Regional Open Learning Centre (SEAMOLEC) will 
(i)  train and mentor other SEAMEO regional centers in the use of online tools for 
work collaboration, meetings, webinars, and conferences among each other, with 
priority to members of the Centers Policy Research Network; 
(ii)  set up and assist a community of practice among knowledge management and 
information technology (IT) officers and staff across all SEAMEO regional centers, 
and provide lecture and mentoring on how to organize and maintain a community 
of practice; 
(iii)  assist SEAMEO regional centers in planning and procurement of IT to upgrade 
their capacities for online work collaboration; and  
(iv)  provide lectures, workshops, and mentoring on the use of appropriate freeware 
for interregional center online work collaboration between the regional centers. 
 
9.  SEAMEO Regional Centre for Education in Science and Mathematics. As a lead 
center  and  in  cooperation  with  the  SEAMEO  Regional  Centre  for  Quality  Improvement  of 
Teacher and Education Personnel (QITEP) in Science and SEAMEO QITEP in Mathematics, 
the Regional Centre for Education in Science and Mathematics (RECSAM) will  
(i)  develop  an  inventory  of  science  and  technology  educational  and  training 
programs in Southeast Asia; 
(ii)  develop and provide training on innovative methods of teaching science and 
mathematics,  such  as  the  Activity,  Student,  Experiment  and  Improvisation 
through Planning, Doing, while Seeing then Improving approach, by exploring the 
methods for an ASEAN-wide application; and 
(iii)  organize the Southeast Congress on the Search for SEAMEO Young Scientists 
(SSYS) in support of the LIFYL (module 4) of SEAMEO College. 
 
10.  SEAMEO Regional Centre for Graduate Study and Research in Agriculture. As a 
lead center and in cooperation with SEAMEO BIOTROP, SEAMEO Regional Tropical Medicine 
and Public Health Network (TROPMED), and SEAMEO Regional Centre for Food and Nutrition 
(RECFON), SEAMEO SEARCA will  
(i)  conduct collaborative policy research among relevant SEAMEO regional centers 
and partners on issues raised in the SDEM (modules 1) for education ministers 
and the HOCCS (module 2) for high-level policy makers such as education for 
green development, disaster risk reduction, climate change adaptation, the post-
Education for All framework and agenda beyond 2015, and others; 
(ii)  develop a postgraduate or special course on natural resource management and 
poverty reduction in support of priorities and common issues raised by education 
ministers and high-level policy makers or senior education officials in the SDEM 
(module 1) and HOCCS (module 2); and

Appendix 3  13 
(iii)  organize  forums  to  promote  mainstreaming  of  green  technologies  and 
development in Southeast Asia. 
 
11.  SEAMEO Regional Centre for Vocational and Technical Education. As a lead center 
and in cooperation with SEAMEO RECSAM and SEAMEO QITEP in Language, SEAMEO 
Regional Centre for Vocation and Technical Education (VOCTECH) will  
(i)  assess  enrolment  trends  in  SEAMEO  member  countries  and school-to-work 
transitions of graduates; 
(ii)  conduct surveys of industry and employers’ associations in Southeast Asia to 
assess emerging cross-border human resource issues and trends; 
(iii)  provide capacity building courses on vocational and technical education and 
training based on the results of the assessment and survey; and 
(iv)  conduct supply and demand forecasting of human resources in ASEAN based on 
recent shifts in the regional production networks and the revealed comparative 
advantage of each ASEAN country. 
 
B.  International Consultants (about 36 person-months)  
 
12.  Module development experts (about 12 person-months—4 persons for 3 months each, 
intermittent). The experts will 
(i)  develop the course content, taking into consideration the audience, nature of the 
module, time allocation, and resources; 
(ii)  prepare a presentation plan and an outline or set of talking points on the topic; 
(iii)  provide  a  full  paper  (in  Microsoft  Word)  and  presentation  (in  Microsoft 
PowerPoint)  to  the  project  management  team  at  least  4  weeks  before  the 
session; 
(iv)  develop course or supplementary materials for the session and submit them to 
the project management team along with the full paper; 
(v)  present the paper consistent with the following suggested points—objectives, 
outline of presentation, introduction, major points and examples, and conclusion 
and recommendations; and  
(vi)  provide feedback to the PMO on the conduct of the session through a meeting or 
written statement. 
 
13.  Manager,  project  management  office  (for  SEAMEO  College) (24 person-months 
[1 person for 24 months]). The manager will  
(i)  supervise  all  work  at  the  PMO,  including  overseeing  of  liquidation  and 
reimbursement  of  TA  funds,  in  coordination  with  the  SEAMEO  Secretariat 
finance office;  
(ii)  monitor the implementation of all TA activities;  
(iii)  liaise with development partners and prepare project proposals for their funding;  
(iv)  coordinate  with  the  SEAMEO  Secretariat  and ADB  for  the  delivery  of  office 
equipment to be procured by ADB; and  
(v)  represent SEAMEO College in external functions and events. 
 
C.  National (Thai) Consultants (72 person-months) 
14.  Project  officers,  project  management  office  (for  SEAMEO  College)  (72 person-
months [3 persons for 24 months each]). The officers will 
(i)  assist the manager of the PMO in various technical and administrative tasks to 
implement TA activities; and

14  Appendix 3 
 
(ii)  perform other duties as assigned by the manager of the PMO.  
 
D.  Resource Persons (about 220 working days [22 persons for 10 days each], intermittent) 
 
15.  Eminent persons (about 60 working days [6 persons for 10 days each]). They will 
(i)  share visions for an integrated ASEAN Community by referring to the role of 
education and HRD;  
(ii)  give  forward-looking  lectures  on  new  and  common  regional  agreements, 
frameworks, and standards in education and HRD in ASEAN as part of capacity 
building modules; and 
(iii)  suggest  innovative  solutions  to  ASEAN-wide  as  part  of  capacity  building 
modules education and HRD issues, mainly related to the development of 
new regional agreements, frameworks, and standards. 
 
16.  Prominent scholars, professionals, and representatives from the private sector 
(about 70 working days [7 persons for 10 days each]). These persons will provide specific inputs 
to the advisory board. They will  
(i)  advise on the policy, programs, and content of SEAMEO College; 
(ii)  provide expertise to guide the policy and programs of SEAMEO College; 
(iii)  assist  in  advocacy  and  communication  (e.g.,  serving  as  ambassadors  for 
SEAMEO College); 
(iv)  help  connect  to  potential  partners  and  obtain  funds  or  other  support  from 
development partners; and 
(v)  provide voluntary work to assist in the implementation of SEAMEO College.  
 
17.  Regional experts on education and human resource development issues (about 
70 working days [7 persons for 10 days each]). The experts will provide specific inputs to the 
project management committee. The experts will  
(i)  periodically evaluate the performance of, and provides direction to, the PMO; 
(ii)  formulate or approve work plans and guidelines for the PMO; 
(iii)  help the SEAMEO Secretariat identify resource persons; 
(iv)  review and approve the budget, and examine periodic financial statements;  
(v)  help  connect  to  potential  partners  and  obtain  funds  or  other  support  from 
development partners; and 
(vi)  provide overall management oversight of the PMO. 
 
18.  Education policy research experts (about 20 working days [2 persons for 10 days 
each]). The experts will 
(i)  prepare and deliver workshops on education policy research and practice in 
policy research tools;  
(ii)  conduct regional and country case studies, which will complement the research 
to be done by SEAMEO regional centers in support of the HOCCS (module 2); 
and 
(iii)  assess  the  learning  process  of  capacity  building  modules  and  suggest 
improvements in delivering capacity building modules.
author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB   –  Asian Development Bank 
  AEC  –  ASEAN Economic Community 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  GMS  –  Greater Mekong Subregion 
  HOCCS  –  high officials country case studies 
  HRD  –  human resource development 
  PPP  –  Phnom Penh Plan 
  SDEM  –  Strategic Dialogue for Education Ministers 
  SEAMEO  –  Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organization 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TVET  –  technical and vocational education and training 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional–Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Education (preprimary and basic education, nonformal education, 
upper secondary education, technical education and vocational 
skills training, tertiary and higher education) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Social development (human development), capacity 
development (institutional development, organizational 
development), regional cooperation and integration (other 
regional public goods) 
Location (impact)  –  Regional (high), rural (low), urban (low), national (medium) 
Partnership  –  Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
 
GLOSSARY 
 
college  –  An organized body of persons engaged in a common pursuit or having 
common interests or duties, or a collegial body that is not always an 
institution with a physical structure. 
innovation  –  The  introduction  of  a  new  idea,  method,  or  device,  which  can  be 
generated from informal and open dialogues among innovators. 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  J. Nugent, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Director  L. Gutierrez, Human and Social Development Division, SERD 
   
Team leader  Y. Hirosato, Principal Education Specialist, SERD 
Team member  J. Mangahas, Social Sector Specialist, SERD 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
